div.p: 1. The current general word for movement of any kind, psychological as well as physical, is dòng 動 (ant. jìng 靜 "remain still").
2. Yí 移 (ant. dìng 定 "fixed, unoved") refers to any temporary or lasting dislocation to a new place.
3. Xǐ 徙 (ant. liú 留 "stay put") refers to moving permanently, often but not necessarily over a long distance.

4. Qiān 遷 (liú 留 ("stay put") refers to moving and/or changing permanently, and particularly moving radically, or over a long distance, and the word often refers to dignified or someohow sanctioned movement.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／
CC JIUZHANG 08:01; SBBY 251; Jin 606; Huang 112; Fu 120; tr. Hawkes 178;
后皇嘉樹，橘徠服兮。 1 Fairest of all God's trees, the orange came and settled here,
受命不遷，生南國兮。 Commanded by him not to move, but only grow in the South Country.
深固難徙，更壹志兮。 Deep-rooted, firm and hard to shift: showing in this its singleness of purpose;

bibl.title: A Dictionary of Selected Synonyms in the Principal Indo-European Languages

note.p: Long discussion of MOTUS versus MOTIO "action".

bibl.title: Anthologia sive Florilegium rerum et materiarum selectarum

entry.def: The current general word for movement of any kind, psychological as well as physical, is dòng 動 (ant. jìng 靜 "remain still").

sense.def: move about (e.g. of fish in the water). This is the general term for movement in any plane and of any kind.
BUDDH ?? cause to move > set (thoughts, feeling, the mind, dharmas, etc.) in motion

entry.def: Xǐ 徙 (ant. liú 留 "stay put") refers to moving permanently, often but not necessarily over a long distance.

sense.def: move house; move place, move about, move around; change course; migrate; move abroad
cause to move; prod into action
move; stir (a fish while frying it etc); rake up (mud)

CHEMLA 2003: move along on the calculating boardBù 步 refers to a specific movement leftwards of a number on the calculating surface, and this concept was later referred to as jìn 進. The mathematical antonym is 折, which later came to be more transparently designated by the word 退. JZ 4.16: 借一算，步之，超一等 "One 'borrows' one counting rod and moves it leftwards (in Chinese terms: forward!), in each movement of this kind jumping across one column." [NB: this 等 comes from the Song edition, and in Daizhen edition the text is wèi 位. If Dai's reading is to be relied on, then this will mean that the meaning of wèi 位 "decimal position" is attested already in the Nine Chapters.]

entry.def: Yí 移 (ant. dìng 定 "fixed, unoved") refers to any temporary or lasting dislocation to a new place.

sense.def: mover N1 to the place N2

bibl.title: 簡明古漢語同義詞詞典

sense.def: (of heavenly bodies or the four seasons) take their course, move along one's course
cause to proceed, cause to move, make move
retiring, withdrawing movement of the body
move so as to make traces in the earth
of abstract things: move as far as

entry.def: Qiān 遷 (liú 留 ("stay put") refers to moving and/or changing permanently, and particularly moving radically, or over a long distance, and the word often refers to dignified or someohow sanctioned movement.

sense.def: move to another place, move one's capital;
change one's ways; change one's ways to; transfer (to another person)
move towards/move to (a place); move about in (a place)
move N1 to (or in relation to) place N2
move so as to settle in
fidget about in, mess about in
move freely about in general, move
spread the contextually determinate objects among or in N2
ritually governed movements of stepping forward and back
move up and down; ascend and descend
